description: From Middle French brut, from Old French brut, from Latin brūtus (“dull, stupid, insensible”), an Oscan loanword, from Proto-Indo-European *gʷréh₂us (“heavy”). Cognate with Ancient Greek βαρύς (barús), Persian گران‎ (gerân) and Sanskrit गुरु (gurú) (English guru).

adjectives.description: brute (comparative more brute, superlative most brute)

entries.meaning: Without reason or intelligence (of animals). [from 15th c.]
Characteristic of unthinking animals; senseless, unreasoning (of humans). [from 16th c.]
Unconnected with intelligence or thought; purely material, senseless. [from 16th c.]
examples: the brute earth; the brute powers of nature
I punched him with brute force.

entries.meaning: Brutal; cruel; fierce; ferocious; savage; pitiless.
(archaic) An animal seen as being without human reason; a senseless beast. [from 17th c.]
examples: they laid before them how unbecoming it was the Dignity of such sublime Creatures to be sollicitous about gratifying those Appetites, which they had in common with Brutes, and at the same time unmindful of those higher qualities that gave them the preeminence over all visible Beings.

entries.meaning: A person with the characteristics of an unthinking animal; a coarse or brutal person. [from 17th c.]
examples: One of them was a hulking brute of a man, heavily tattooed and with a hardened face that practically screamed "I just got out of jail."

entries.meaning: (film, television) A kind of powerful spotlight.
examples: For a scene like the Highgate exhumation night sequence suitable equipment would consist of: two brutes on Molevators, three 10 K lights also on Molevators and, for good measure, two 5 Ks, four 2 Ks, two pups (1000 W), two North lights  […]

entries.meaning: (archaic, UK, Cambridge University slang) One who has not yet matriculated.

verbs.description: brute (third-person singular simple present brutes, present participle bruting, simple past and past participle bruted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shape (diamonds) by grinding them against each other.

verbs.description: brute (third-person singular simple present brutes, present participle bruting, simple past and past participle bruted)
